SENT.plain: Cerebral venous sinus thrombosis is an uncommon yet potentially life threatening condition which is often under-diagnosed or misdiagnosed because of the variability of the clinical signs and symptoms
The imaging findings are often subtle thus the need for a high index of suspicion
The superior sagittal and transverse sinuses are the most frequently involved
The correct diagnosis of cerebral venous thrombosis relies on neuroimaging studies
The two cases reported highlight the fact that the radiologist may be the first clinician to suspect and diagnose this condition
This ultimately affects prognosis as early diagnosis and treatment reduces morbidity and mortality
